The Baku International Humanitarian Forum, which is annually attended by heads of states and governments, Nobel Prize laureates, and internationally renowned public and political figures, has already become a tradition. In 2011, Azerbaijan won Europe's top music competition, the Eurovision Song Contest, while in 2012 we successfully hosted this competition in Baku, thus demonstrating our great potential to the world.

The Seventh UN Forum on Internet Governance was held in Baku in 2012. The fact that this forum was held in Azerbaijan was no coincidence, as the ICT sector is rapidly developing to become the most promising segment of our economy. In fact, 2013 was declared “The Year of ICT" in Azerbaijan.

On February 8, 2013, Azerbaijan launched its first telecommunications satellite into orbit. It was a very significant and historic day, and a major achievement for our country. The decision to put an Azerbaijani satellite into orbit was made in 2008. In 2009, we adopted a relevant state program, Azerkosmos JSC was established in 2010. The results we have achieved show that Azerbaijan is indeed a rapidly and comprehensively developing country today. Two more satellites will be launched into orbit in 2015 and 2016, which will create excellent opportunities for the development of the space industry in Azerbaijan. The development of new technology, in particular the ICT sector, has become a hallmark of Azerbaijan and will facilitate our successful development in the future.

Over past decade, Azerbaijan has successfully hosted a number of globally important political, economic, cultural, sporting, and other events. In addition to that, the European Olympic Committee's decision to conduct the inaugural 2015 European Olympic Games in Azerbaijan is not only a historic achievement and a huge success for our country, but it is also evidence of Azerbaijan's growing international authority and a recognition of our extensive opportunities on the part of the international community.

In parallel with this, democratic reforms are being continued and a strong civil society has emerged in Azerbaijan. Today, Azerbaijan is a country where freedom of expression, speech, and the media are guaranteed. People and the prosperity of our nation are at the heart of all our policies. All of our steps and work serve the interests of the people of Azerbaijan. Of course, we could not implement such gigantic plans without the confidence and support of our people.

Regarding the upcoming election, what can you say about the future of the country and the key policies you intend to implement?

More than 20 years ago, Azerbaijan freed itself from a totalitarian system and has been on the path of democratic state building ever since. At the sensitive time when our Republic had just regained its independence, it was vitally important for our people who and what force would come to power in Azerbaijan. The bitter experience of the early 1990s shows that the rise to power of completely accidental people, unaware of their responsibility for public administration, can lead to tragedy and expose the state to serious problems. The people of Azerbaijan are very wise and have always been able to make the right decision at crucial times in their history. When our statehood was faced with the imminent threat of destruction in 1993, our people stood up and invited national leader Heydar Aliyev, who had tremendous experience in public administration, to power. The consistent implementation of the development strategy laid down by Heydar Aliyev for over 20 years has secured our dynamic development and transformed Azerbaijan into a modern and democratic country on the world map.

There are certain unchangeable principles of building a modern and democratic state, a system of values that are consistently secured, and main strategic goals that are always protected. I am absolutely convinced that the course toward building an independent state, democratic development, social prosperity, and civil society laid down by Heydar Aliyev must continue in Azerbaijan. Of course, the top priority of this policy is that Azerbaijan should stand among the most developed countries of the world, be competitive, restore its territorial integrity, and be an independent, strong, and democratic state.

Given the important geostrategic location of Azerbaijan, how would you describe the country's relations with Russia, Turkey, and other neighboring nations?

Azerbaijan is a reliable partner that has its own position on any issue and pursues a completely independent policy. With the exception of Armenia, we build our relations with countries in the region and the world on the basis of the principles of effective cooperation, mutual respect, and non-interference in each other's affairs. It was on these principles that Azerbaijan joined the Non-Aligned Movement (NAM) in 2012, thus identifying new vectors of the country's foreign policy. As with any other country in the world, we are currently working to strengthen our relations with African and Latin American countries and establish new partnerships.

The development of relations with regional countries remains a priority direction of our foreign policy. Turkey is a friendly and brotherly country and a strategic ally for Azerbaijan. The transnational projects implemented by Azerbaijan's initiative in recent years, as well as mutual investment projects, have brought our countries even closer together. We are currently implementing a project on the construction of a petrochemical and refinery complex in Turkey worth $17 billion. Azerbaijan's major energy projects enhance the importance of Turkey as a transit country and a contributor to European energy security.

As was the case in previous years, our relations with Russia are also rapidly developing. Our relations have assumed the nature of a strategic partnership. Political dialogue, humanitarian cooperation, the strengthening of economic relations, and collaboration on other issues form the core of our bilateral agenda. Russia is in first place for the volume of imports to Azerbaijan. At the same time, Russia is an important market for our agricultural produce. We have recently started to invest in real estate and the shares of major commercial entities in Russia. Azerbaijani companies are also implementing projects in the area of agricultural produce processing in Russia, for example.

Furthermore, Azerbaijan is developing friendly and sincere relations with other countries in the region. We are guided by the interests of the Azerbaijani people and the state in bilateral and multilateral relations.

The year 2012 was declared “Year of Sports." Reflecting on Azerbaijan's achievements at the Olympic Games in London 2012, the hosting of the FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup, and the election of Baku to host the inaugural European Olympic Games in 2015, how would you evaluate this past year?

Our achievements in the field of sports in 2012 gives us the opportunity to talk about the results of the “Year of Sports" with a sense of great pride. When making this decision at the beginning of 2012, we wanted our athletes to win and to succeed, and they have lived up to our expectations. Our athletes have successfully represented our country in international competitions, winning a total of over 700 medals in various tournaments, including 255 gold medals. About 300 international sports events have been held in Azerbaijan in the last 10 years. Of these, I want to particularly highlight the FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup, because it was a new and very successful experience for us. Both FIFA and UEFA have given a very high assessment of the organization of the World Cup in Azerbaijan. In 2013, we marked the 20th anniversary of the National Olympic Committee. Azerbaijan has been a member of the international Olympic family for 20 years now. The historic results of our athletes at the London Olympic Games in 2012 are further evidence of the fact that our country is already a full-fledged member of this family. Our athletes have won 10 medals at the Olympics, including two gold, two silver, and six bronze. We finished in 30th place in the world, in 15th among European nations, and in third among Muslim countries.

Finally, on December 8, 2012, a session of the General Assembly of the European Olympic Committee held in Rome decided to conduct the inaugural European Olympic Games in 2015 in Baku. I believe that this is a historic decision. Historically, the Olympic Games originated in Europe, but the European Olympic Games have never been held before. The decision to conduct the first European Olympic Games is in itself a very serious step, a watershed in the Olympic movement. It is a tremendous responsibility for us to host Europe's first Olympics, but it is also a high assessment on the part of the international and European Olympic movement of the work being done in our country, including our achievements in the field of sports. The ever-growing international authority of Azerbaijan, the country's economic power and dynamic development, the modern social, economic, and cultural infrastructure, the existing public and political stability, and the popular support for the reforms being implemented have played an important part in the adoption of this decision.

However, we had started to create a modern sports infrastructure suitable for conducting important international competitions in Azerbaijan long before the decision was made. In 2012, these activities were continued and two more regional Olympic centers were commissioned, bringing the total number of Olympic centers in the country to 35. Eight other centers are currently under construction and there are plans to build several more. New sports facilities have been built and put into operation in Baku. The country's central stadium has been renovated in accordance with international standards. Another stadium has also been commissioned. The construction of a large Gymnastics Center and an Aquatic Palace is currently under way. In 2012, we laid the foundation for the Olympic stadium, which will be the largest stadium in the region. I am absolutely sure that the infrastructure and technical and organizational issues will be successfully resolved for the inaugural European Olympic Games in 2015. I would also like to note that host countries are usually allowed six to seven years to prepare for the Olympic Games, but we have only two years to go. This is why we have already started to take the necessary actions. On January 17, 2013, we established the Organizing Committee for the First European Olympic Games, which held its first meeting on February 2, and discussed future objectives and tasks. I am sure that all relevant organizations will do their best to conduct the Games at a high level and we, as ever, will demonstrate the power of our country, the hospitality of our people, and the dynamic development of Azerbaijan to Europe and the world.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Lord Green began his career with the Ministry of Overseas Development. In 1977, he joined management consultants McKinsey & Co Inc, with whom he undertook assignments in Europe, North America, and the Middle East. He joined HSBC in 1982 with responsibility for corporate planning activities and in 1985 was put in charge of the development of the bank’s global treasury operations. In 1992, he became Group Treasurer of HSBC Holdings and in 1998 he became Executive Director of the same bank. His is currently Minister of UK Trade and Investment.
node.title: A Business Legacy
node.richbody0content:
How would you assess UK-Azerbaijan trade relations?

The UK government places a great deal of importance on trade relations with Azerbaijan. Although Azerbaijan is a young country, it has an increasing presence on the international stage and I am proud to say that the UK is a friend and strategic partner of Azerbaijan. However, our relations go back much further than you may think. In fact, the first British businessman is said to have visited Baku 500 years ago, and I'm pleased to say that today British firms are the principal foreign investors in Azerbaijan, making up 50% of all FDI. The shared benefits of this cooperation are clear. Fast-developing economies like Azerbaijan are vital drivers for growth, and UK expertise and industry has been helping modernize and develop many sectors, including oil and gas and infrastructure. Azerbaijan is making a significant push to develop its IT sector, and we're also involved in developing this area. Our relations are underpinned by trade, but the scope of our relationship is widening all the time.

Does the energy sector play the largest part in this relationship?

Absolutely. With BP at the forefront, the UK has strong business links with Azerbaijani companies in the energy sector and related services. UK companies have invested over $25 billion in Azerbaijan. However, there is so much more to Azerbaijan than energy. Of course, Azerbaijan will want to exploit the opportunities that its wealth in energy resources brings, but at the same time I am pleased to see that Azerbaijan is looking to the future and realizes the need to diversify its economy on more sustainable ground.

What opportunities are there for UK companies outside of the energy sector?

There are over 120 UK businesses operating in Azerbaijan. There are many strengths and interests that the UK and Azerbaijan share and should build on. While trade between our countries has grown in recent years, speaking to business people in the UK, I am convinced that this can grow further and farther than it has so far. There are many business opportunities that neither one of us is taking advantage of. I would like to see more of our companies, especially our SMEs, doing business with each other. The UK has a powerful and diverse brand and no matter where we are in the world, our products are always associated with high quality, whether it be in fashion or education. As Azerbaijan prospers from its natural resources, its citizens are increasingly looking to purchase higher-end goods and services, and this is an area where we see UK-based companies moving. We are already seeing growth in the retail sector, with a particular focus on luxury brands and well-known household names. UK retail outlets currently in Azerbaijan include Burberry, Mothercare, Debenhams, and Accessorize. There is also increasing interest in the education sector, both from UK universities and Azerbaijani students. The UK has some of the finest schools and universities in the world, and I am pleased to see that the number of applications from Azerbaijan has doubled in the past couple of years. Both Heriot Watt University and Nottingham Trent University have a significant presence in Azerbaijan. Other priority sectors for UK companies are in financial services, construction management, and design. The challenge for us now is to build on what has been achieved so far and further strengthen our business links, because there is so much for both of our countries to gain.

What impact did the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympics Games have on the UK's reputation abroad?

The Olympics and Paralympics were a very proud moment for the people of London and the UK. It was not only an opportunity to showcase British sporting ability, but also an opportunity to promote the UK as a place to visit, work, and study. I am delighted that Azerbaijan has been selected to host the inaugural European Games in summer 2015. While much of the necessary infrastructure is already in place or under contract, there are still likely to be opportunities in sports consultancy and communications. Given the experience of the London 2012 Olympics and Paralympics, there will be many UK companies well placed to compete. I know that the Head of the British Olympic Association, Lord Sebastian Coe, has already visited Baku to congratulate Azerbaijan on its success and discuss areas for further cooperation. However, with all this attention on Azerbaijan, it is inevitable that the world will look closely at the country's progress across a broad range of issues. There is still some way to go to convince a large number of UK companies to invest confidently in Azerbaijan. I hope that Azerbaijan will continue to improve its business climate, enticing yet more UK companies to invest in a country with huge potential.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Riyad Huseynov was born in 1982 and graduated from the Azerbaijan State Economic University’s Finance and Credit Department. Prior to joining Synergy Group as Chairman of the Supervisory Board in 2012, he worked in the Ministry of Taxes. In 2006, he became Assistant to the Minister of Taxes and was later promoted to the position of Head of the International Relations Department.
node.title: Five Stars in Growth
node.richbody0content:
How would you characterize 2012 for your operations with the new management team?

Synergy Group operates a dynamic portfolio of a number of diverse and growth-oriented businesses. With the new supervisory and executive boards, our business is focused on running companies more efficiently, selecting best-of-breed partners, investing in intellectual and financial capital, and fostering an entrepreneurial culture in which talented professionals can develop. Moreover, the new management and operations team comprised of young and talented professionals has clear short- and long-term agendas followed by a solid implementation mechanism, which goes fully in line with the vision of the shareholders for the prospects of the company's development.

In which sectors have you been the most successful so far, and what sectors are you looking at for further expansion?

Our company continues to expand throughout this dynamic market at the crossroads of the EU and Asia. We are very active in manufacturing and the production of construction materials, hospitality, agriculture, education, and IT. Our subsidiary, Renaissance Construction Azerbaijan, which performs large-scale projects in the private and governmental sectors, helps us to implement the latest techniques as well as cutting-edge technology. Meanwhile, construction and IT are among the most successful of our businesses and are of great importance to Synergy Group. In parallel with that, we are also constantly assessing new opportunities for further expansion, and therefore we are planning to enter the financial market in the near future.

What impact has Eurovision, the U-17 UEFA cup, and other international events in 2012 had on hotel occupancy?

It is obvious that such major international events positively influence the tourism and hospitality sectors, enabling growth and development. At the same time, they create brilliant opportunities to increase the country's visibility worldwide and to bring in tourist flows, which not only has a positive impact on economic development but also on Azerbaijan's recognition as a country with a unique tourism brand. We have been operating hotels in the region of Nabran and Naftalan, and we strongly believe that Azerbaijan has all the opportunities to provide leisure activities for both foreign visitors and the local market. Setting the example, Renaissance Construction Azerbaijan is currently working on the construction of Qala Altı Hotel Spa & Resort in Shabran, a five-star hotel in Shamkir, and projects in Sheki and Lenkoran. These are illustrations of our projects aimed at the development of tourism in Azerbaijan.

“Synergy Group is now expanding its IT business by transferring our know-how to the Central Asian market."

In terms of the construction materials industry, Synergy Group is rapidly developing its direction. Can you outline the priorities?

Overall, 2012 has been very successful for Synergy Group subsidiary AAC, which was the first company in Azerbaijan and the Caucasus region to produce cellular aero concrete. This unique product, which has fundamentally changed the technology and timing of construction work, has already been in great demand in the EU over the last few years. In Azerbaijan, it is being produced by AAC under the brand name Gobustone, which has excellent sound-insulating and high energy-saving properties. Therefore, we are proud to state that AAC is a pioneer in the production of aero concrete in the local and regional markets, and it is already exporting its products to countries around the CIS. When choosing technology, we thoroughly take into account the environmental impact as well as economic effect. We are constantly developing new methods and technologies, and strive to expand the scope of our activities. Benefiting from our best expertise, we are proud to be a supplier of major construction sites for Pasha Construction, which is building Port Baku Towers and Residence, the 28 May Shopping Mall, the National Gymnastics Academy in Baku, as well as the Shahdag Summer-Winter Tourism Complex. Among our customers is ZQAN Holding, with large-scale construction projects, such as the Rixos Hotel in Guba and the Trump Tower in Baku.

The ICT sector is the recipient of the largest amount of non-oil FDI. Is Synergy Group benefiting from those investments?

Today, we can firmly state that our IT company CyberNet, which has been a technology development leader since its establishment in 2004, is one of our most successful businesses. CyberNet laid the foundation and presently leads a number of IT projects, which benefits both the public and private sectors. The Automated Tax Information System (AVIS), a one-stop shop for business registration, e-tax services for entrepreneurs, e-tax auditing, the information system of the cadaster of immovable property, the automated documentation system for the State Committee of Property, as well as the e-government information system for the Ministry of Communication and Information Technologies are just a few examples of the many successful projects developed by CyberNet. It goes without saying that there are a number of other major projects that we have implemented for the government and private sector institutions that have had a significant impact on the ease of doing business in Azerbaijan. Synergy Group is now expanding its IT business by transferring our know-how to the Central Asian market.

How would you characterize the current investment climate in Azerbaijan? Is it likely to change during the 2013 Presidential elections?

Due to the strategic view of the President of Azerbaijan, a favorable investment climate was created in the country. This in turn paved the way for billions of dollars to flow into the country's economy. Moreover, wise and consistent efforts are being made by the state's leadership to develop the non-oil sector, which will foster opportunities for small-, medium-, and large-scale businesses. This ensures the sustainable growth of the economy and lays the foundations for the prosperous life of future generations. Synergy Group clearly illustrates one of many examples of successful companies that enjoy the well-established investment climate in Azerbaijan.

How would you describe the changes in Azerbaijan's business landscape over the last 10 years?

The regulatory environment in Azerbaijan has undergone significant positive changes over the last decade. A number of reforms have been made and some are underway in the field of business registration, as well as access to finance, tax administration, and business permit and license acquisitions. As a result, Azerbaijan was ranked as a top reformer in the ease of doing business according to the World Bank's Doing Business report. This clearly demonstrates the effectiveness of the existing business environment, and is recognition of the reforms by international financial institutions.

Looking forward to 2013, what are your business objectives for the Synergy Group?

In addition to our Business Development Strategy for 2013-2015, we aim to become a solid market player as a private equity company with a key focus on construction and the production of construction materials, IT, and agribusiness. We have all the necessary expertise and resources to make this goal happen. Being a rapidly growing company, we highly value the core basis of our success; our people. The growth of the business has set the company the task of ensuring that we have a team ready for change, rather than being merely reactive. In a one-year perspective, we aim to work in a way that will enable Synergy Group, with its diversified business portfolio, to be a smart example of successful business management.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: HRH Crown Prince Haakon was educated at the Royal Norwegian Naval Academy, and later obtained a BA in Political Science from the University of California, Berkley. He joined the Norwegian Foreign Ministry, and completed its trainee program for diplomats in 2001. He went on to receive a Master’s in Development Studies from London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE), specializing in international trade and African development. He carries out a wide variety of official engagements in Norway, is the patron of a host of organizations, and was appointed as a Goodwill Ambassador for the UN Development Programme.
node.title: Walking the Corridors
node.richbody0content:
Norway is very pleased with the close relationship that has developed between our countries in the energy sphere and the increasingly close cooperation between Statoil and the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR). The Norwegian supply industry has also made substantial deliveries to projects in the Caspian Sea area. The Caspian region plays an increasingly important role in the world energy market. Azerbaijan has long proven itself to be a reliable and important partner as a producer of oil and gas, and our two countries share the ambition of being reliable suppliers of energy to Europe. Azerbaijan has a key role to play as the enabler of the Southern Gas Corridor, which will link the Caspian region even closer to Europe. Norway fully supports the Southern Gas Corridor, which will further enhance Europe's supply security. The corridor is important to many European countries.

Azerbaijan's oil history dates back as far as the 1840s, and Norway's experience goes back to the late 1960s. Statoil was among the first international oil companies to invest in Azerbaijan when independence was re-established and international oil companies were invited in. Both Azerbaijan and Norway face the challenge of making sure that our energy resources are managed in a sustainable manner. We must ensure that the resources will also benefit our children and grandchildren, thus taking a long-term perspective in resource management.

To reflect on the situation of Azerbaijan based on Norway's own experience, I believe that when a substantial part of the national income is generated by oil and gas exports, it is particularly important that we have clear and transparent rules and practices governing both the extraction of resources and the handling of the revenues generated. Too many countries have experienced the so-called “resource curse," where short-lived money flows have led to massive social disparities, inflated spending, and a lack of control of a vital national reserve. Hence, our joint focus on the need for long-term strategies, environmental responsibility, and transparency is crucial. Azerbaijan's focus on the environment and the establishment of a national oil fund is commendable. Norway also hopes to see a continued dialogue on other topics for the mutual benefit of our two nations, such as regional stability, security, human rights, and democracy.

“Both Azerbaijan and Norway face the challenge of making sure that our energy resources are managed in a sustainable manner."

I am pleased about Norway's cooperation with Azerbaijan in the framework of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI), where countries and companies work together to promote transparency, accountability, and good governance. We commend Azerbaijan for embracing this initiative at a very early stage and for setting an important example.

It is also worth mentioning the growing importance of being attached to corporate social responsibility. Governments, commercial entities, and civil societies all have important roles to play in creating a solid basis of sustainable development for the benefit of the entire society. Azerbaijan's role in the global energy market is already important, and its role is set to become even more significant in the future. I hope to see the mutually beneficial partnership between Azerbaijan and Norway develop in the years to come, both in the energy sphere and in other areas.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Héctor Mata was born in the Puerto Plata Province of the Dominican Republic in 1953. He studied Agricultural Engineering at the University of Santo Domingo, and in 1990 received his Master’s in Animal Production from the National University of Pedro Henriquez Urena. He also holds degrees in Human Development, Design and Evaluation of Social Programs and Investments. He began working in the Ministry of Agriculture as a Rural Administration Zonal Manager in 1981. Since 2000, he has worked as an Assistant Representative for FAO.
node.title: Make More, Make Wiser
node.richbody0content:
How would you rate development in the agriculture sector in the Dominican Republic, and what role does the Food & Agriculture Organization (FAO) play?

In terms of production, the agriculture sector has had its ups and downs over the years due to changeable weather conditions in the Dominican Republic. Around 70% of farms are small-scale producers, and crops are mainly rain fed. The sector does, however, combine some old techniques with advanced technology. In general, rice and vegetables production incorporates advanced technology, and beans and corn use old technology. Over the last few years we have seen a shift toward organic crop varieties. These have begun to gain weight in the country's overall production basket, especially in terms of organic bananas. The Dominican Republic is the leading exporter of this product worldwide, and our main markets are Europe and the US. In this regard, FAO and other international organizations like the UN are implementing a plan to strengthen organic banana production in the country. For example, we are conducting research and launching a pilot project to determine the best irrigation system for this type of crop, and now we are focusing on how to make such technology available to small- and medium-sized producers. Also, FAO aims to strengthen the position of organic bananas by providing the product with value-added in order to make it more competitive on the international stage. Another of our main projects has to do with agricultural diversification, so farmers do not depend on one type of crop.

What is behind the success of organic farming in the country?

We have learned how to work closely with farmers and to advise them, but at the same time to listen to their worries and needs. That has enabled us to better target the demands of big markets like Europe. In addition, the introduction of advanced technology in the sector has added competitive value. Before, farmers used to focus on producing crops through old methods without paying attention to market demands, and fortunately we have achieved a mindset and cultural change in this field. Overall, I believe that it is a vital strategy to follow, especially when it comes to small-scale producers who now tend to look for synergies with other producers through the creation of a small network in the production chain.

What value-added is FAO working on promoting within the organic farming segment?

We believe that by increasing agribusiness competitiveness and trying to provide lower-income families access to essential products, we can add value to Dominican products like cocoa, coffee, and bananas. However, I would like to stress that FAO is mostly focusing on providing advice and expertise to small-scale producers, because in the banana and coffee industries, which are very important for the national economy, there is an entire network of associations that unite efforts in order to provide much-needed strength to products in international markets.

What needs to be done to improve the livestock and fisheries industries?

The livestock sector, especially the milk production segment, still depends very much on international markets and their evolution. However, there has been a very positive evolution over the last 10 years, and figures show that we have gone from producing 400 million liters of milk per year to 688 million liters, according to public data. The increase has been 72% in a decade, which means a more-than-100% increase in overall milk production figures at the national level. The country currently imports 70% of its meat and fish needs. The fishing industry is suffering from a lack of new technology and investment, and it has yet to be fully developed. In addition, the country needs to work on the quality of its production in these two particular areas. For all that to happen, the country needs to attract much-needed FDI and expertise, because these industries hold huge potential but lack the economic resources.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Milagros Ureña has a degree in Biochemistry from Pedro Henrí­quez Ureña National University and has also studied Business Administration, Industrial Psychology, and Human Resource Management at both the undergraduate and post-graduate level. Having had a long career in the health and education sectors, as well as being an advisor on projects with the Finance and Tourism ministries and the Dominican Social Security Institute, she has been in charge of CEDIMAT since 2001.
node.title: Technology Graft
node.richbody0content:
In 2012 the first heart transplant was performed in the Dominican Republic. How important a milestone is this for the country's health system?

Completion of the first heart transplant in the country represents proof of the evolution of the ability of Dominican cardiovascular medicine to provide medical care. On the one hand, this fact proves the technological development that has been achieved, but on the other hand it reveals the lack of a national policy regarding the sustainability and implementation of an enduring heart transplant program. A successful transplant program in emerging economies requires government involvement to ensure its continuity.

When will CEDIMAT's cardiovascular medicine center be operational, and what means will it have?

The center will be operational in January 2014. The center will consist of seven floors, 150 beds, and diagnostic, therapeutic, and surgical procedures will be performed there. The center is already considered one of the most advanced in Latin America in this specialty and others, and the blueprints have been certified to international standards. We will perform a type of medicine that will give the country a great boost to assert itself in the medical tourism field.

How have you been sourcing specialists for the center?

In terms of human resources, we already have a good team of medical specialists, but we are also training personnel in France, Spain, and the US. They will be joining the center once it starts operations. We also have proposals from foreign doctors who want to work at the center, and we will also have them working with us. The most important thing is that Cedimat has served as a magnet so that Dominican professionals abroad choose to return to the Dominican Republic to practice their professions. The main reason is that at CEDIMAT, they find the same technology, the same working conditions, and the same scientific environment to develop their specialties as they have been doing in developed countries.

CEDIMAT has a telemedicine system permanently linked to Massachusetts General Hospital. How important is it for CEDIMAT to have an open line of communication with such a prestigious US institution?

It is extremely important because our doctors can teleconference regarding a patient and take advantage of this medium as a means of training. Our operating rooms have a telemedicine system that allows us to consult with doctors from other hospitals located around the world. For example, a doctor from the Massachusetts General Hospital can participate live in a surgery being performed at CEDIMAT. Similarly, we do teleconferences with other medical centers in the country, during which personnel can interact, discuss medical cases, and even participate remotely in a surgery. This system is extremely important to keep doctors up to date, and it benefits patients as several specialists may be intervening simultaneously in a medical procedure from different locations.

What potential do you see for the development of medical tourism in the Dominican Republic?

The Dominican Republic has great potential to develop medical tourism, but so far it is in its early stages because there is no state policy to develop it. The initiative should have its origin in breakthrough policies in this new tourism model coming from the Ministry of Tourism. Medical tourism is a new opportunity for the Dominican Republic because we have great comparative advantages, such as our proximity to developed countries like the US and Canada, with the former having a large number of uninsured citizens and high medical costs. It is estimated that in the US there are about 40 million people without insurance, and medical service costs are among the highest in the world. The proximity to the Dominican Republic would allow us to capture a percentage of this market, which could come here instead of going to India, for example, which is much further away. In addition, the country has extraordinary access infrastructure with seven international airports and sophisticated communication systems, as well as a high-quality hotel industry.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Born in 1941, Juan José Hidalgo has a wide range of business experience in various countries around the world. In 1991, he headed a group of investors to acquire Air Europa, a company operating regular flights. Through this, he broke up Iberia’s monopoly over domestic flights in Spain. Today, he is Executive President of Grupo Globalia, a leader in the tourism sector.
node.title: Unique Experiences
node.richbody0content:
How has this country contributed to the growth of Globalia over the years?

Overall, it has been a very successful story with a lot of satisfaction, much effort, and many investments. We have a large corporate structure in the Dominican Republic and 4,000 employees, for whom I would do absolutely everything. Over the years, we have reached an investment level of around $400 million.

The Dominican Republic in particular, and the Caribbean region in general, is the main destination for 14% of Air Europa's international passengers. What are the future prospects regarding these touristic destinations?

Air Europa will maintain its daily flights from Madrid to both Santo Domingo and Punta Cana, as well as some other specific flights to Puerto Plata. Currently, we are analyzing and exploring the possibility of diverting some of our operations to La Romana.

What will the new Boeing 787 Dreamliner bring to the company's fleet?

It will be part of a unique experience for our customers traveling to and from the Dominican Republic. The Boeing 787 Dreamliner is considered the plane of the future; it is much more comfortable, quieter, and consumes 30% less fuel. When traveling on it, passengers should be reminded that they are certainly traveling in the most modern aircraft available on the market. At least two of the eight such aircraft that the company owns will be flying between the EU and the Dominican Republic.

Air Europa started flying to Puerto Plata in June 2011. What are your future expectations for this destination, and how would you assess the results up until now?

We have high hopes about Puerto Plata's present and future. We own two hotels that are practically new, with the most advanced technology and modern settings, and we currently have direct flights to Puerto Plata from Madrid. We are putting great efforts into internationally promoting Puerto Plata through our Travelplan network and Halcón Viajes, as well as through tour operators in the US, Venezuela, Puerto Rico, and basically all the countries where we work. I must say that it is not an easy task, for the competition is tough.

Be Live Hotels, the group's hospitality chain, launched a tour around several American countries in 2011 to present its new image in the Caribbean. Which countries do you focus your efforts on?

Our image is currently associated with quality and the perception that our hotels transmit feelings and sensations, as well as the culture of the country where we operate. Currently, our investment in hotels is greatly focused on the Dominican Republic, a country where we own establishments. Elsewhere in the Americas and the Caribbean region, we only manage the hotels.

Do you think the franchise business model can work well in the Dominican Republic?

My answer is clear; why not? We would be delighted to franchise the brand under high-quality standards. We would have higher commercial volumes, and applying economies of scale, we would certainly be more competitive.

In your opinion, what are the main competitive advantages of the Dominican Republic as a destination compared to its tourism competitors?

The Dominican Republic is a sweet and kind country, in which everybody is looking for the best way to assist you. And they do so with sympathy and really good work. That already makes the country stand out when compared to other destinations. In addition, visitors can enjoy beautiful beaches and landscapes, and soon there will also be a good motorway network. In my opinion, it is an ideal country that lies only four hours away from the US by plane. I believe that it certainly has a bright and promising future ahead.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: HE Saeed Abdul Jalil Al Fahim is the Chairman of Al Fahim Group. He is also the Chairman of the International Investment Bank (Bahrain), President of the Sheikh Khalifa Excellence Award, and Chairman of the Mubarak & Brothers Property & Financial Investment LLC. He has a degree in Business Administration from Bowling Green University. He was also awarded an Honorary Doctorate in Business Administration for his contribution to rural development in 1995.
node.intervieweelist0name: HE Saeed Abdul Jalil Al Fahim
node.previewsummary: "To succeed you have to keep improving, and this continuous ambition is central to our success."
node.title: Deal on
node.richbody0content:
What steps has Al Fahim Group taken to attain its current position in the UAE automotive industry?

The late Abdul Jalil Al Fahim (mercy upon him), my father and the founder of AlFahim Group, left strong values that have guided us toward making the right decisions. These values include substance, foresight, humanity, honesty, and we have recently added innovation. These values have guided investment in flagship facilities and a focus on our staff and customers that ensure we deliver excellent products and services across all our businesses. Customer satisfaction is number one in our business, and we change processes and offers constantly to ensure we maintain our leading position. We have a clear strategy based upon the “product leadership" value discipline, which has enabled the business to clearly focus on its priorities and innovation to strengthen our position. Clear key performance indicator (KPI) targets and performance-based management systems provide clarity and drive the business forward.

What trends have you noticed across your dealerships over the past six months?

There has been a definite market recovery over the last six months in both our passenger car and commercial vehicle businesses. The country is thriving and we can witness this through our commercial vehicle business, which sells truck and van fleets for construction companies, oil and gas corporations, hotels, and more. When these entities start ordering large fleets of trucks for construction sites, buses for public transportation, or vans for hotel shuttles and limousines, this means there is confidence in the real estate market and preparations for population growth. Within passenger car operations, sales are increasing and bank financing is more available, assisting customers to purchase cars. Our developing after-sales services also highlight our commitment to customer loyalty and satisfaction.

How did you adapt your business strategy during the economic downturn?

The downturn reminded us to focus on our core strengths and run a tighter business. We maintained our structure and teams as we focus on the longer term and ensure that we deliver customer satisfaction. We have sophisticated inventory management systems and procedures that have allowed us to react quickly to the changes in market demand. These have served us very well during the downturn and recovery period. For example, by studying feedback from our customers we launched solutions to encourage customer retention, such as customized service contracts for Mercedes-Benz commercial vehicles and passenger car owners. Due to this strategy, we maintained high scores in customer satisfaction ratings, reaching over 95% in sales, further emphasizing the vision, mission, and values of the group.

“To succeed you have to keep improving, and this continuous ambition is central to our success."

What opportunities do you see in the UAE's automotive sector?

The sector is vibrant and growing. We will always seek to offer new solutions to meet our customers' needs and new complementary products that fill market demand. We see growth in the premium sector, especially within the small car segment. For instance, when the Fiat 500 by Gucci and Fiat Abarth 695 Tributo Ferrari were launched in the market, we increased year-on-year sales by 50%. Mercedes-Benz has also seen the opportunity for this segment in the UAE, and has recently launched the long-awaited A-Class. Our first consignment virtually sold out within a few days. In 2012, we saw a growing interest in requests for customizations, showing there is a trend in the market for individuality. We now have a “Bespoke" edition of the CLS/ML and GL, offering a much sportier look to the V8 models. We also have a range of super luxury Vito vans available for our customers. In parallel, we also look to grow our share of the super luxury sector further, with the new S-Class Mercedes-Benz, which is among the favorite models of high-income businessmen and VIPs. On a broader level, we are witnessing a more environmentally aware generation emerge, showing hybrid cars will grow in popularity.

How are Al Fahim Group's dealerships encouraging Emiratis to enter the workforce?

Al Fahim Group has implemented a special employment strategy in line with the initiative of His Highness Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan, President of the UAE, including the Absher initiative to enhance the participation of UAE nationals in the labor market. We have established this exclusive recruitment strategy in line with the Absher initiative's four main pillars: the provision of job opportunities in all sectors, rehabilitation and training, guidance and counseling, and encouraging nationals to work in the private sector to support the policies of Emiratization. In April 2013 we held an open day at our premises in Mussafah, where over 30 Emirati men and women attended to learn more about customer service, career development, and share their CVs for potential employment at Al Fahim Group. Al Fahim Group's recruitment plan includes 80 UAE nationals in Al Fahim Group's workforce in the coming five years across our diverse business members. Our efforts to attract Emiratis are driven by our corporate social responsibility as a local company, but also by our deep belief that by raising the participation rate of UAE nationals in any organization structure we will support its competitiveness, sustainability, and stability. It is our duty as a local company to strive toward providing a decent standard of living for UAE nationals and securing stable job opportunities guaranteeing a brighter future for them and increasing the rate of employment of Emiratis across all industries.

Which Mercedes models have been historically popular at your flagship dealership Emirates Motors Company?

The most popular model at Emirates Motor Company has always been the luxurious Mercedes-Benz E-Class, yet in 2012 the CLS was one of the most admired models, witnessing a 41% increase compared to the same period in the previous year. The SUV range is also a highly regarded segment at Mercedes-Benz with the Mercedes-Benz GL and M-Class. Naturally, we also have a large customer base of sporty car enthusiasts, with which the Mercedes-Benz SLK and SL are popular.

The UAE's automotive industry was up 12%-18% in 2012. What were some of your highlights?

Within Emirates Motor Company, we witnessed growth in our SUV segment by 53%, sports segment by 32%, and the Mercedes-Benz CLS by 64%, while Jeep Grand Cherokee showed a strong growth of over 44% across all models. Overall, we had our best year ever in sales volumes and seek to grow further in 2013. We owe this accomplishment to many milestones our automotive business members have observed in the last few years, building up to this moment. Besides housing the largest Mercedes-Benz facility in the world right here in Abu Dhabi, our al-Ain automotive operations have also seen a surge in performance in 2012. We announced our partnership with the Department of Transport (DOT) in al-Ain, where a new state-of-the-art bus service and maintenance center operated by our al-Ain branch, Eastern Motors, was inaugurated. The DOT public bus maintenance and service center comes exclusively to service al-Ain's 100 public transport Mercedes-Benz buses. Additionally, due to a rise of over 17% in Michelin tires by Eastern Motors since 2009, reaffirming the increase in demand for professional car servicing to passenger cars, especially SUVs, the dealership launched one of the most professional tire-fitting centers in the city in 2012.

Coming off the back of a high-performing year, how do you plan to sustain growth?

Our expectations continue to rise and we have a growth strategy for 2013 and beyond. Our management is targeted to deliver to customer expectations and grow market share. We are supported by strong principles and have the best facilities. We are investing in al-Ain this year and look forward to growth and success across all our operations. In the city of Abu Dhabi we will be announcing an expansion of the airport road facility for Emirates Motor Company. As for Central Motors & Equipment, another one of our automotive business units, we are opening TYREPLUS, a new tire center to provide convenient and quality tire services through our sole distributorship of Michelin. We also intend to expand our operations with ADNOC to offer Bosch Car Service to everyone in the community. On a more tactical and customer-focused level, we have corporate affinity programs in place as well as flexible payment solutions for individuals. We are also participating for the second time in the Sheikh Khalifa Excellence Award, using the opportunity to showcase our development since our last involvement in 2007. To succeed you have to keep improving, and this continuous ambition is central to our success.

© The Business Year - May 2013

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Rovshan Najaf obtained a Bachelor’s degree in International Economic Relations from the Azerbaijan State Economic University and a Master’s degree in Public Administration from the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University. He then went on to work in a variety of positions at the Ministry for Economic Development, including Chief Adviser of the Investment Policy Division, Head of the Foreign Economic Relations Department, and Assistant to the Minister. He began working with the Azerbaijan Investment Company in December 2010, serving as Deputy Executive Director. He has been Executive Director since 2012.
node.previewsummary: TBY talks to Rovshan Najaf, Executive Director of the Azerbaijan Investment Company (AIC), on integration with global markets, the company's strategy to increase the amount of non-oil FDI flowing into the country, and the various economic sectors with high potential.
node.title: Actively Engaged
node.richbody0content:
What steps led to the formation of the Azerbaijan Investment Company (AIC)?

The rapid growth of the non-oil sector is crucial to reducing Azerbaijan's dependence on hydrocarbons. Monetary reserves expanding on the waves of the recent oil boom ensure new opportunities for diversification, and these funds are being used for the development of the non-oil sector and the attraction of foreign investment. Obviously, integration into the global economy is the driving force behind the policy of diversification. The last eight years have seen a four fold increase in the non-oil sector of Azerbaijan's economy, which currently holds a leading position among CIS countries. To maintain its competitiveness, Azerbaijan has prioritized the facilitation of investments via public-private partnerships (PPP). In this context, the establishment of AIC in 2006 was an obvious step forward in implementing the government's policy of diversification. AIC is a state-owned equity fund pursuing the objective of supporting development in the non-oil sector of the national economy via termed-equity injections in partnership with local and foreign investors. The integration of new technology and know-how and the promotion of modernization, innovation, and competitiveness are among the priority objectives of AIC, as well as contributing to the development of the capital markets.

What synergy exists between AIC and the Azerbaijan Export and Investment Promotion Foundation (AZPROMO)?

We at AIC are privileged to have a powerful sister company in AZPROMO, working along the same frontiers of promoting Azerbaijan and its natural and intellectual resources. AZPROMO and AIC jointly offer a solid foundation for foreign investments in commercially viable projects in Azerbaijan. Both companies are dedicated to promoting Azerbaijan, with AIC focusing on equity investments in projects aimed at developing the non-oil sector of the national economy.

President Aliyev is actively trying to increase the amount of non-oil FDI that comes into the country. What are AIC's specific strategies to realize this?

AIC is an effective vehicle designed to implement the President's vision and guidelines for the prosperous future of Azerbaijan. AIC upholds the concept of supporting local and foreign investors interested in commercially feasible projects in the non-oil sector of the national economy, and adheres to principles of strict compliance with international corporate governance standards. As a state-owned investment company, AIC's engagement in projects is always based on minority shareholding, without being a burden on other stakeholders. AIC is limited to representation at the board level only. In addition to equity investment, we are also here to offer our expertise in current market trends in the priority sectors of the national economy, identify investment opportunities for foreign and local investors, and provide technical support in carrying out and preparing market research and surveys, as well as in the development of business plans.

“Integration into the global economy is the driving force behind the policy of diversification."

Which non-oil sectors are currently seeing the most interest from foreign investors?

Logistics is currently seeing a lot of interest from foreign investors. Located at the crossroads between Asia and Europe, Azerbaijan is the most stable country in the region in both economic and political terms. Bridging Europe and Central Asia, as well as connecting Northeastern Europe with the Middle East, Azerbaijan is also a logistics hub for the entire Caspian region. AIC is actively engaged in assessing projects in this sector with potential partners. Industry is also seeing a lot of interest. The country has always been at the forefront of regional industrial development. Along with oil and natural gas extraction and processing, engineering, metallurgy, and electricity generation form the pillars of the manufacturing industry. The government has already prioritized the development of the latter three segments of manufacturing with a particular focus on chemical engineering, which saw the establishment of Sumgait Chemical Industrial Park LLC on December 21, 2011. The initiative will serve the purpose of creating a favorable and simplified business environment to develop a competitive chemical industry via innovative and cutting-edge technology. The alternative and renewable energy sector in Azerbaijan is as attractive to investors as mother nature has prescribed it. Azerbaijan offers the most favorable climatic conditions to foster a renewable energy industry. For solar panels, we have over 280 days of bright sunshine a year, and for wind turbines Azerbaijan offers a guaranteed continuous supply of strong winds throughout the year. The Caspian sees high tidal cycles and an abundance of fast flowing mountain rivers for hydropower plants, and last but not the least, the soil in Azerbaijan is renowned for its arable qualities, and is capable of producing a high yield of biomass. Tourism is also a fast-developing industry in Azerbaijan. The government is investing heavily in infrastructure to facilitate tourism in the country following the “Year of Tourism" in 2011. In 2012, Azerbaijan hosted the Eurovision Song Contest and the FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup. A number of five-star luxury hotels with global brands have also opened their doors in Baku in the recent years. The initial phase of the Shahdag Summer-Winter Tourism Complex is also nearing completion. Recently, Azerbaijan successfully won the bid to host the first European Olympic Games in 2015. Azerbaijan also has ambitious plans to host the Olympics and the UEFA European Football Championship in the near future. ICT is yet another industry in Azerbaijan that attracts remarkably high interest from local and foreign investors alike. For investors in ICT, Azerbaijan offers excellent infrastructure. The country is launching its first satellite into space in 2013, which will offer tremendous opportunities in telecommunications and IT, not only in the country, but also in the region at large. As recently as November 2012, President Aliyev declared the establishment of a high-tech industrial park in the country, which will, yet again, offer investors a favorable business environment. Azerbaijan prides itself on its high literacy levels (99.6%) and excellent IT and foreign language skills. The State Program on Education Abroad has been in operation since 2007, a part of which includes government sponsorship of national students studying abroad. A considerable number of these students are choosing ICT as a university degree. Finally, agriculture is also attracting foreign investor interest. Food security and regional development are among the top priorities for Azerbaijan. The country has the most favorable climatic conditions and affordable tax regime in the region. In partnership with RAO Global Group GmbH, we at AIC have launched the “Aghstafa Agroservice" project to support local farmers to increase productivity and boost the efficient use of topsoil by providing all kinds of agro-technical services. The project has proven to be a great success, and we are already planning to expand the network of service hubs to other regions of the country.

Which sectors are currently the priority for AIC to promote and how?

Industry is one of the obvious priorities in Azerbaijan. AIC has been actively involved in a number of successful projects targeting industry development in the non-oil sector of the national economy. A new, state-of-the-art cement production facility with dry output of cement and clinker has been launched in partnership with Holcim—one of the world's leading suppliers of cement and aggregates—and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). Holcim-Azerbaijan OJSC is one of the largest cement producers in the region, and it has recently increased its production capacity with less pollution and energy use. Yet another success story for us is the Baku Shipyard Plant project that we are involved in together with the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR) and Keppel Corporation, one of the world's largest offshore and marine groups with a global network of 20 shipyards and offices.

Agriculture and food processing are vital components of Azerbaijan's non-oil economy, and they have significant potential for boosting the country's export revenues. While agriculture only accounts for 7% of GDP, it is still a key source of jobs and is a priority in the context of food security. In food processing, AIC is engaged in a project in partnership with one of the largest local holding companies. The project saw a new salt production facility constructed just outside of Baku to produce high-quality refined and iodized salt. We are also holding equity in a dairy production project in partnership with the EBRD and a number of local investors. A new milk processing plant has already been launched as an outcome of the project.

Looking back at the past 10 years of President Aliyev's administration, how would you say the investment climate has changed?

The personal dedication and perseverance committed by Ilham Aliyev, the President of Azerbaijan, over the past 10 years have brought dramatic changes to the country's investment climate. Continuous improvements in Azerbaijan's macroeconomic environment earned the nation 18th place in the relevant pillar of the Basic Requirements Index of the Global Competitiveness Report 2012-2013 by the World Economic Forum, which ranked 144 world economies. The favorable business environment sustained in Azerbaijan has attracted investments in excess of $136 billion, about $70 billion of which is attributed to FDI.

The high impact changes introduced in the macroeconomic environment of the country have resulted in a substantial increase of the private sector's share in national GDP, which stands at 83% at present. Notably, the 2009 Doing Business report published by the World Bank and IFC puts Azerbaijan in the leading position in terms of the quality of reforms carried out to improve the business environment in the country. The improved business environment along with rises in public expenditure, according to the Transition Report 2012 published by the EBRD in December 2012, was a stimulus for the accelerated expansion of the non-oil sector.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0company: State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ)
node.intervieweelist0description: Shahmar Movsumov is a graduate of the International Economic Relations Faculty of Moscow State Institute of International Relations, and has a Master’s in Public Administration from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. After graduation, he worked for an extensive period from 1995 to 2005 at the National Bank of Azerbaijan Republic, becoming its General Director in 2005, before moving to the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ) as Executive Director in 2006. Since 2006, he has also served as Chairman of the Government Commission on the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative.
node.previewsummary: TBY talks to Shahmar Movsumov, Executive Director of the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ), on the fund's growing and diversifying investment portfolio and its contribution to the evolution of wealth and development in Azerbaijan.
node.title: The New Asset Mix
node.richbody0content:
Could you describe the scope of the activities that the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan (SOFAZ) is active in?

President Heydar Aliyev established SOFAZ back in 1999 as an integral part of the government's oil strategy. The first stage of this strategy involved the development of oil and gas fields in cooperation with major foreign oil and gas corporations. The second stage was focused on establishing multiple oil and gas transportation routes connecting Azerbaijan with major international markets. The third stage of the strategy involved the establishment of SOFAZ, with the main purpose to maintain transparent and prudent management of the country's oil and gas revenues. One of SOFAZ's main objectives is the preservation of macroeconomic stability by insulating the economy from oil revenue volatility, decreasing dependence on hydrocarbons, and stimulating the development of the non-oil sector. The second objective is to ensure intergenerational equality with regard to the country's oil wealth. Non-renewable natural resources are converted into a diversified portfolio of international financial assets, which generates perpetual income for current and future generations. The investment portfolio is only invested in assets outside of Azerbaijan, and until 2012 it was mostly allocated to fixed-income securities denominated in three major international currencies. In 2012, we diversified into new markets by adding exposure to new asset classes, namely gold, real estate and equities, and different currencies. The third objective is allocating resources for funding major socioeconomic projects. For instance, we have completed financing the state's share in the Baku-Tbilisi-Ceyhan (BTC) pipeline construction project. Currently, we are financing the construction of the Baku-Tbilisi-Kars (BTK) railroad and the construction of the settlement for refugees and internally displaced persons who were forced to flee their native lands as a result of Armenia-Azerbaijan, Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. Furthermore, we are funding the “State Program on the Education of Azerbaijani Youth Abroad from 2007-2015," which provides full scholarships to Azerbaijani students studying in leading international universities. In 2013, we are starting a number of new projects in cooperation with the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic (SOCAR)—we will begin funding the Trans-Anatolian Pipeline (TANAP) project, which is an integral part of the Southern Gas Corridor and will allow the transit of gas to Europe.

What would you say were some of your major achievements in 2012?

I would say that 2012 was a milestone year for SOFAZ. We modified our investment strategy to include several new asset classes and started building a diversified, multi-asset class portfolio, thus enhancing the expected return of our investments. Our conservative, risk-cautious investment strategy served us well in the past, enabling the fund to avoid incurring losses during the turbulent years of the global financial crisis or a low-yield environment, and prevailing in the financial markets in the post-crisis period, which substantially limited its performance. As in every new beginning, each one of these new instruments has brought its challenges. However, the capacity we have built over the years, from both a human resources and infrastructure point of view, has enabled us to successfully overcome those obstacles.

SOFAZ has recently made some high-profile real estate acquisitions in Paris and London. What led you to make these decisions regarding the purchase of real estate?

According to SOFAZ's current investment guidelines, up to 5% of its investment portfolio may be allocated to real estate. Our current investment strategy with regard to this asset class is aimed at building a globally diversified portfolio comprised of core assets in key cities around the globe. All of the potential investments are thoroughly analyzed along several parameters, such as price, location, quality, current tenants, and development potential. The highest-scoring properties are acquired.

Are you involved in any projects in Azerbaijan to improve state infrastructure?

Only large-scale projects of national significance are financed by SOFAZ. Over 2013, in addition to the projects I mentioned earlier, we will start funding a fiber-to-the-home project aimed at providing broadband internet access to every house in the country. This project has significant potential for moving forward the telecommunications sector in Azerbaijan.

How much of SOFAZ's portfolio is in gold, and what made you decide to acquire that asset?

In accordance with our current investment policy, up to 5% of our investment portfolio may be allocated to gold. We started our investments in this asset class in February 2012 and acquired around 15 tons of gold by the end of the year. In 2013, we are planning to increase our gold holdings to 30 tons, and we have already started transporting it to Azerbaijan. As an asset class, gold has several unique characteristics that makes it attractive for investors. In the long run, gold is considered to act as an effective instrument for hedging inflation and currency risks. Moreover, gold offers protection from heightened volatility in financial markets during economic downturns as it is negatively correlated to both equity and fixed income.

How would you characterize the evolution of Azerbaijan's investment climate over the last decade?

I recently attended a farewell dinner for one of the ambassadors who spent roughly 10 years here. In his words he said, “I came to one country and I am leaving a totally different country." During his 10 years here, Azerbaijan has absolutely transformed itself into a new country. Wide-ranging economic reforms implemented by the government have resulted in notable progress to improve regulatory efficiency and encourage domestic economic diversification, especially in the areas of agriculture, tourism, and ICT. The government invested in the development and modernization of the country's infrastructure, laying the foundation for private sector investments in the country. Azerbaijan has enjoyed measurable success in diversifying its economy outside of the energy sector, with the non-oil portion of the economy growing significantly.

What further strategies do you have for 2013?

Overall, 2012 was marked by the fund entering public equities, real estate, and gold markets. At the same time, we have added new currencies to our investment portfolio—the Australian dollar, the Russian ruble, and the Turkish lira. In 2013, we will continue building up our exposure to these asset classes and further diversify our investment portfolio. We are planning to increase our exposure to equities, both public and private. We will also strengthen our position in real estate. At the moment, we are exploring new regions for attractive investment opportunities in real estate.

What are your medium-term plans for SOFAZ?

Over the next few years, we plan to expand institutionally and professionally. We are looking forward to further increasing our allocation to equities and alternative assets. These financial instruments are expected to perform better than fixed income in the long-term perspective. This is in line with the long-term investor nature of the fund. On a separate note, we have always managed the majority of our assets in-house. That way, we are able to gain valuable experience and a deeper understanding of those markets. During the initial stages of our investments in the new asset classes, we decided to employ the know-how and expertise of the largest players in those markets. For instance, our public equity portfolios are currently being managed externally. However, we are planning on gradually increasing the fund's involvement in the management of those assets, while keeping an eye on cost efficiency. In the meantime, we will be building the internal capacity necessary for efficient in-house management by investing heavily in staff training and developing necessary systems and practices.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Angel Terrero has been with Yobel Logistics since 2003, and was previously a Production Supervisor at Abbott Hospital. Prior to that, he spent four years between 1998 and 2002 at Plásticos del Caribe as a Process Engineer. He has an educational background in supply chain management.
node.title: Selling Points
node.richbody0content:
What market factors led to the establishment of Yobel in the Dominican Republic?

Yobel Logistics has over 40 years of experience and professional service dedicated to optimizing processes in supply chains through its specialized business units. In addition, we are the first company in the Latin American region to offer outsourced service in supply chain management in 13 countries: Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Mexico, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, and the US. Yobel was established in the country 10 years ago, offering something unique in the sector—supply chain management focused on logistics services. Our activity in the country has become a key business branch for the company, because we have experienced an average annual growth of 25% thanks to our unique offering. We provide physical infrastructure, technology, and qualified and skilled labor. I believe that such an offering is one of our main competitive advantages, and at the same time, the company has benefited significantly from the economic development of the Dominican Republic in the last few years. Today, both local companies and international enterprises form our client portfolio, which currently consists of 10 companies.

How would you rate the workforce in the Dominican Republic?

There are many different groups in the country's workforce; those within the minimum wage group can be described as extremely hard working and very flexible, whereas administrative and management employees are highly qualified at a national level. In the past few years, there has been an important increase in the number of locals pursuing higher education studies in the US and other countries. We have experience in working with all three groups of people, and I can say that such experiences have been very fruitful and successful.

What is Yobel's potential for developing manufacturing services in the Dominican Republic?

Although Yobel offers manufacturing services elsewhere, we have yet to develop these activities in the Dominican Republic. It is a matter of the size of the market; we have manufacturing, including customization and production services in Mexico, Guatemala, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Colombia, and Peru, which are large markets and offer good infrastructure services to export to other countries. If a business opportunity to develop such activities in the country arises, we would analyze its feasibility and future potential. Now, we can see that the national economy tends to focus on the service sector, and we understand that both the authorities and the private sector are aiming to develop production and manufacturing industries with value-added. Yobel can expect to play a key role in developing this industry in the Dominican Republic. We believe that the externalization of manufacturing and production activities is the best option in terms of profitability and economic viability, with the option to share the manufacturing costs with other companies.

What are Yobel's main investment lines in the country?

Our investment policy is based on reinvesting our profits, and this aggressive approach is due to the growth of the country. In terms of areas of investment, we mostly focus on developing know-how, innovation, and technology, as well as building strong teams of professionals through training courses. One of our main aims is to implement new services for our clients and widen our service portfolio. For example, over the last few years we started offering agency services to improve efficiency. Since we are an international company, we also take advantage of our unique features to offer specialized advice and services based on our experience.

What are the growth prospects for Yobel in the short term?

We expect to close 2013 with a growth rate of around 15% to 17%, and our strategic development plan for the company for the next 10 years foresees Yobel growing at a higher pace than national GDP. We believe there is still a long road ahead of us, with very good growth potential for the company thanks to the economic and political stability the region has achieved. In addition, we are planning to expand our area of operations from 15,000 sqm to 20,000 sqm, as well as increase the number of employees in the country by 20%.

node.author: TBY
node.intervieweelist0description: Jorge Cabeze has over 14 years of experience in the IT sector, where he began his career as at a subsidiary of Microsoft as a Technical Manager of the Organization Customer Unit as well as later working at IBM for a short time. He has been involved in the development of many Microsoft projects and held various titles while at the company. He studied Systems Engineering at Los Andes University in Colombia.
node.title: Cloud Nine
node.richbody0content:
How is the Dominican Republic placed within the region in terms of the competitiveness and maturity of the technological field?

I believe there is a lot of potential in the Dominican Republic in terms of the evolution of ICT. One way to develop it is with enterprise companies. These companies evolved in 2011 in terms of usage of ICT as a mechanism for business development. These companies are using ICT to provide more services to their customers. Take the banking, insurance, and mining sectors, for example; they have many uses for ICT and are pushing hard to provide more services. This type of usage would be the average across the region; however, there are still many opportunities for ICT to develop across SMEs that could be used to increase services and make them more agile.

How big an influence has piracy had on the take up of the Windows operating system in the Dominican Republic when compared to the other countries in the Caribbean and Latin America?

The usage of Microsoft Plus! is one of the highest in the region. Although Microsoft products have a high penetration rate, piracy remains a problem. This country has one of the highest rates of pirated software use in the region, close to 74%. The problem is SMEs, because these types of companies make up the majority. We need to educate SME owners that ICT is an investment that will make their businesses more agile and prosperous. However, the government is willing to work with us and we are making progress. It is important to understand that piracy affects everyone, not only Microsoft. Piracy affects the technology industry as well as the music and film and arts industry. In the end, piracy has a negative effect on the economy as well as the knowledge economy of a country, thus hindering innovation.

How are you educating small- and medium-sized organizations, and what has been the response?

We are working with many organizations in the country to show SME organizations that ICT is an investment and not an expense. The response has been modest so far; however, I think this government is looking to focus on formalizing these organizations.
